verses.text: This is the book of the generations of Adam. When God created man, He made him in the likeness of God.
verses.comment: Mankind is made in the image and likeness of God, a truth echoed in the New Testament regarding the new creation in Christ (Colossians 3:10).

verses.text: Male and female He created them, and He blessed them and called them 'Man' when they were created.
verses.comment: This verse reinforces humanity as created by God, both male and female, also highlighting the importance of blessing.

verses.text: When Adam had lived 130 years, he fathered a son in his own likeness, after his image, and named him Seth.
verses.comment: Adam’s descendants bear his image, signifying the transmission of human nature.

verses.text: The days of Adam after he fathered Seth were 800 years, and he had other sons and daughters.
verses.comment: The long lifespans parallel ancient near eastern genealogies but may hint at a spiritual significance concerning humanity’s original closeness to God.

verses.text: So all the days that Adam lived were 930 years, and he died.
verses.comment: Death enters the world as a fulfillment of God’s warning in Genesis 2:17.

verses.text: When Seth had lived 105 years, he fathered Enosh.
verses.comment: The lineage continues, establishing the line through which the promise is preserved.

verses.text: Seth lived after he fathered Enosh 807 years and had other sons and daughters.
verses.comment: Genealogical records in Scripture underscore the continuity of God’s blessings through generations.

verses.text: So all the days of Seth were 912 years, and he died.
verses.comment: The repeated phrase 'and he died' echoes the consequence of sin—death as a separation from God.

verses.text: When Enosh had lived 90 years, he fathered Kenan.
verses.comment: This detailed genealogy points toward the faithful transmission of faith and promise through the generations.

verses.text: Enosh lived after he fathered Kenan 815 years, and had other sons and daughters.
verses.comment: The record of long generations lays the groundwork for the unfolding salvation history.

verses.text: So all the days of Enosh were 905 years, and he died.
verses.comment: 'He died' marks the universal effect of sin, ultimately overcome by Christ (Romans 5:12-21).

verses.text: When Kenan had lived 70 years, he fathered Mahalalel.
verses.comment: Each generation's detail is preserved, illustrating the value of tradition and continuity.

verses.text: Kenan lived after he fathered Mahalalel 840 years, and he had other sons and daughters.
So all the days of Kenan were 910 years, and he died.
When Mahalalel had lived 65 years, he fathered Jared.
Mahalalel lived after he fathered Jared 830 years, and had other sons and daughters.
So all the days of Mahalalel were 895 years, and he died.
When Jared had lived 162 years, he fathered Enoch.
verses.comment: Enoch's appearance here is significant, as the text will highlight his unique walk with God (see v. 22-24; Hebrews 11:5).

verses.text: Jared lived after he fathered Enoch 800 years, and had other sons and daughters.
So all the days of Jared were 962 years, and he died.
When Enoch had lived 65 years, he fathered Methuselah.
verses.comment: Enoch’s line is associated with faithfulness, prefiguring those saints who would be translated into the presence of God.

verses.text: Enoch walked with God after he fathered Methuselah 300 years, and had other sons and daughters.
verses.comment: To 'walk with God' is a phrase indicating deep communion and obedience; Enoch is later seen as a model of sanctity (Sirach 44:16, Jude 1:14).

verses.text: So all the days of Enoch were 365 years.
verses.comment: Enoch’s relatively short life in contrast with others draws attention to a significant event.

verses.text: Enoch walked with God, and he was not, for God took him.
verses.comment: Instead of 'and he died,' Enoch is taken—interpreted as bodily assumption, a foreshadowing of Christ’s ascension and the resurrection hope for believers.

verses.text: When Methuselah had lived 187 years, he fathered Lamech.
verses.comment: Methuselah is remembered for his long life; his name marks the era before the flood.

verses.text: Methuselah lived after he fathered Lamech 782 years and had other sons and daughters.
So all the days of Methuselah were 969 years, and he died.
verses.comment: Methuselah is the oldest recorded human, possibly symbolizing God's patience before judgment (cf. 2 Peter 3:9).

verses.text: When Lamech had lived 182 years, he fathered a son.
He named him Noah, saying, 'Out of the ground that the LORD has cursed, this one shall bring us relief from our work and from the painful toil of our hands.'
verses.comment: The naming of Noah and the reference to relief hints at a messianic hope—a righteous figure who softens the curse, prefiguring Christ's redemptive work.

verses.text: Lamech lived after he fathered Noah 595 years and had other sons and daughters.
So all the days of Lamech were 777 years, and he died.
After Noah was 500 years old, Noah fathered Shem, Ham, and Japheth.
verses.comment: The three sons of Noah become fathers of future peoples, setting the stage for God's covenant to be renewed through Noah, a foreshadowing of baptism and new creation (1 Peter 3:20-21).
